content.shortDescription: Superman, a journalist in Metropolis, embarks on a journey to reconcile his Kryptonian heritage with his human upbringing as Clark Kent.
content.title: Superman

textRecommendations.headline: Superman isn't just another superhero movie, it's got a deep message
textRecommendations.body: Superman is a surprisingly political movie, but in 2025, it honestly feels refreshing that the superhero genre is *finally* tackling real issues in America and calling out the world for what it is. But somehow, director James Gunn doesn’t let the messaging bog down the film, and it still has this great comic book aesthetic to it that looks and feels fun. Plus, Guardians fans will definitely recognize some similarities in a few scenes where Gunn uses excellent cinematography and great music to create memorable moments. Superman is both fun and exciting, but has some real weight behind it.
textRecommendations.bodyHTML: Superman is a surprisingly political movie, but in 2025, it honestly feels refreshing that the superhero genre is *finally* tackling real issues in America and calling out the world for what it is. But somehow, director James Gunn doesn’t let the messaging bog down the film, and it still has this great comic book aesthetic to it that looks and feels fun. Plus, Guardians fans will definitely recognize some similarities in a few scenes where Gunn uses excellent cinematography and great music to create memorable moments. Superman is both fun and exciting, but has some real weight behind it.

profile.bio:
Keith Langston is an entertainment and travel writer who has been obsessed with movies and TV since he was a little kid. From absurd comedies like Strangers with Candy to horror classics like Scream, he’s always loved getting sucked into a great story. 

Experience and Education

Throughout his life, Keith has worked in various parts of the entertainment industry, from being an extra on film sets to doing PR for a television network, and even spending his weekends doing “audience work”. Fun fact: the people you see in the front row of game shows and talk shows aren't actually part of the audience, they're paid actors! Now, as an entertainment writer, Keith has been able to interview some of his favorite celebrities, attend film festivals, movie premieres, and more. He loves that throughout his life he’s built a career where he isn't just watching the entertainment industry from the sidelines, but is actually part of it. On top of contributing to JustWatch, he also writes for People, Digital Trends, Insider, and CBR, among others.

Favourite Movies and TV-Shows

His favorite movies include The Faculty, Clue, Scream, and Deep Blue Sea. His favorite TV shows include Only Murders in the Building, Strangers with Candy, Dead Like Me, and Futurama…he also really enjoyed the Halo series, which was a flaming, epic disaster in the best way possible.  You can follow him on Instagram @KeithFromOhio

textRecommendations.headline: A silly, emotional, action-packed tribute to superheroes and kindness
textRecommendations.body: One of the best superhero movies in years, and one that perfectly adapts the often optimistic, sometimes grim, and perpetually fun world of DC Comics. A strong cast breathes fresh life into their well-worn characters, finding new layers of humanity amidst the genre's typical bombast. A personal movie that builds out a universe organically instead of trying to force a franchise, Superman benefits from rooting itself to an authentically sweet defense of morality in the face of cruelty and the impossible. A truly wonderful movie that will make you feel like your heart has taken flight.
textRecommendations.bodyHTML: One of the best superhero movies in years, and one that perfectly adapts the often optimistic, sometimes grim, and perpetually fun world of DC Comics. A strong cast breathes fresh life into their well-worn characters, finding new layers of humanity amidst the genre's typical bombast. A personal movie that builds out a universe organically instead of trying to force a franchise, Superman benefits from rooting itself to an authentically sweet defense of morality in the face of cruelty and the impossible. A truly wonderful movie that will make you feel like your heart has taken flight.

profile.bio:
Based in Los Angeles, Brandon Zachary is a seasoned entertainment journalist, award-nominated screenwriter, and massive nerd.

Experience and Education

Brandon graduated from Columbia College with a BA in Cinematic Arts & Sciences before becoming a staple at some of the most popular pop culture institutions in the world. You may have seen his work as Contributing Writer with TVBrittanyF and That Hashtag Show, as a Senior Writer at CBR.com or his work at ScreenRant, where he also served as Senior Writer and Editor.

Favorite Movies and TV Shows

As is true with his background, Brandon's tastes are both varied and sundry. When it comes to the big screen, he loves everything from Shaun of the Dead, and Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse to City Lights, Rear Window, and The Shining. When it comes to TV, you can usually read his musings about The Simpsons, Spaced, The Good Place, The Venture Brothers, and The Twilight Zone

textRecommendations.headline: A superhero film that's tailor-made for the romance fans
textRecommendations.body: Relationships are often included in superhero films, but they're rarely centered or as unapologetically romantic as they are in Superman. From the second David Corenswet's Clark Kent and Rachel Brosnahan's Lois Lane share a scene, their banter effectively leaps off the screen and sizzles all throughout. Pair their gorgeous chemistry with the secret dating trope, and Superman delivers a worthy romance that's soft, vulnerable, and so achingly hot. Yes, hot. Scorching, even, with two of the most breathtaking kisses in any superhero film that openly showcase just how remarkably suited they are.
textRecommendations.bodyHTML: Relationships are often included in superhero films, but they're rarely centered or as unapologetically romantic as they are in Superman. From the second David Corenswet's Clark Kent and Rachel Brosnahan's Lois Lane share a scene, their banter effectively leaps off the screen and sizzles all throughout. Pair their gorgeous chemistry with the secret dating trope, and Superman delivers a worthy romance that's soft, vulnerable, and so achingly hot. Yes, hot. Scorching, even, with two of the most breathtaking kisses in any superhero film that openly showcase just how remarkably suited they are.

profile.bio:
Gissane (pronounced geese-enny) is a romance enthusiast who's taken her Master's degree in English and love for essays into writing lengthy analyses about pop culture. She is the founder and Editor-in-Chief of Lady Geeks Media. She's a Tomatometer-Approved critic. When she isn't writing about pop culture, she can be found writing and reading romance novels.

Experience and Education

While completing her Bachelor’s in creative writing and Master’s in English literature, Gissane has been working in the industry for over ten years, covering a wide range of TV shows and movies, while writing romance novels since the pandemic began. Formerly, Gissane was the lead TV editor at CBR, and now, along with JustWatch, she contributes to Fangirlish. 

Favorite Movies and TV Shows

Picking a favorite movie or a TV show is always the hardest, but classics like Roman Holiday, It’s a Wonderful Life, and Moulin Rouge are a huge reason for the type of critic Gissane has chosen to become. She’ll often vocalize that Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again is better than the original, and Pride and Prejudice (2005) is essential viewing for all, not just romance fans. As for TV shows, Ted Lasso will always hold a special place in her heart as well as Parks and Recreation. She’s also a big fan of most Star Wars properties (Obi-Wan Kenobi, in particular) and will run far, far away from horror because she’s too scared.
